case_name: Appellants v. Third Respondent and others

facts.text: This is an appeal, by special leave, from the judgment of the High Court of Punjab and Haryana dismissing Civil Writ No. 3321/1970 filed by the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Mathew, J. This is an appeal, by special leave, from the judgment of the High Court of Punjab and Haryana dismissing Civil Writ No. 3321/1970 filed by the appellants praying for a direction to implement Clause 4. of the Directive of the Union Government dated April 18, 1965, issued under Section 117 of the States Re-organisation Act

facts.text: High Court dismissed Civil Writ No. 3321/1970 filed by the appellants praying for a direction to implement Clause 4 of the Directive dated April 18, 1965 issued under Section 117 of the States Re-organisation Act.

anchor.surface_text: Mathew, J. This is an appeal, by special leave, from the judgment of the High Court of Punjab and Haryana dismissing Civil Writ No. 3321/1970 filed by the appellants praying for a direction to implement Clause 4. of the Directive of the Union Government dated April 18, 1965, issued under Section 117 of the States Re-organisation Act and allowing the writ petitions filed by the third respondent and others praying for an order quashing the final integrated gradation list published on March 11, 1966,

facts.text: High Court allowed writ petitions filed by the third respondent and others quashing the final integrated gradation list published on March 11, 1966 for Clerks and March 20, 1970 for Assistant Head Clerk of the Co-operative Department of Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: and allowing the writ petitions filed by the third respondent and others praying for an order quashing the final integrated gradation list published on March 11, 1966, in so far as it companycerned Clerks and that March 20, 1970, in so far as it companycerned Assistant Head Clerk of the Co-operative Department of the State of Punjab.

facts.text: Merger of Punjab and Pepsu states effective from November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the impending merger of the two states of Punjab and Pepsu with effect from November 1, 1956, it was decided on October 26, 1956, by the Joint Integration Council, that the offices of the Deputy Registrars of Co-operative Societies, Pepsu area, will form a separate division on the basis of the pattern obtaining in Punjab,

facts.text: Joint Integration Council decided on October 26, 1956 that offices of Deputy Registrars of Co-operative Societies, Pepsu area, form separate division on Punjab pattern.

anchor.surface_text: it was decided on October 26, 1956, by the Joint Integration Council, that the offices of the Deputy Registrars of Co-operative Societies, Pepsu area, will form a separate division on the basis of the pattern obtaining in Punjab, In the erstwhile Punjab State, the staff of the Senior and Junior Clerks in the Offices of the Deputy Registrars and Assistant Registrars including Camp Clerks to Inspectors and Sub-Inspectors were placed on divisional cadre in December, 1949,

facts.text: In erstwhile Punjab State, staff of Senior and Junior Clerks in Offices of Deputy Registrars and Assistant Registrars including Camp Clerks placed on divisional cadre in December 1949 by Governor of Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: In the erstwhile Punjab State, the staff of the Senior and Junior Clerks in the Offices of the Deputy Registrars and Assistant Registrars including Camp Clerks to Inspectors and Sub-Inspectors were placed on divisional cadre in December, 1949, by an order of the Governor of Punjab and there were two such divisions in Punjab viz., Ambala and Jullundur and the rules applicable to the service were the Punjab Co-operative Subordinate Service Rules, 1936.

facts.text: Two divisions in Punjab: Ambala and Jullundur; rules Punjab Co-operative Subordinate Service Rules, 1936.

anchor.surface_text: by an order of the Governor of Punjab and there were two such divisions in Punjab viz., Ambala and Jullundur and the rules applicable to the service were the Punjab Co-operative Subordinate Service Rules, 1936. The result was that after the appointed day i.e. November 1, 1956, the staff of Junior and Senior Clerks of each of the three divisions of the companyposite state of Punjab companytinued to be organised as a separate cadre and the officers serving in the office of the Registrar of Co-operative Societies formed a different cadre.

facts.text: After November 1, 1956, staff of Junior and Senior Clerks of three divisions organized as separate cadres; Registrar's office different cadre.

anchor.surface_text: The result was that after the appointed day i.e. November 1, 1956, the staff of Junior and Senior Clerks of each of the three divisions of the companyposite state of Punjab companytinued to be organised as a separate cadre and the officers serving in the office of the Registrar of Co-operative Societies formed a different cadre.

facts.text: Sub-ordinate Judge, Jullundur judgment dated August 2, 1957 based on suit by some Clerks of Registrar's office led to Govt decision for joint state-wise seniority per Punjab Services Integration Rules 1957; promotions provisional.

anchor.surface_text: In the light of certain observations of the Sub-ordinate Judge, Jullundur, in the Judgment dated August 2, 1957, on the basis of a suit filed by some of the Clerk of the Office of the Registrar of Co-operative Societies, the Government of Punjab decided that a joint seniority list must be prepared on State-wise basis instead of divisional basis, in accordance with the Punjab Services Integration Rules, 1957 and that pending preparation of Joint Seniority list, promotions to the posts of Inspectors should be provisional.

facts.text: Registrar of Co-operative Societies, Punjab issued directive on October 13, 1962 to gazetted officers on promotion procedure of Clerks to Assistant Head Clerks based on state-wise joint seniority list.

anchor.surface_text: On Oct. 13, 1962, the Registrar of Co-operative Societies, Punjab, apparently with the approval of the Government, issued a directive to all gazetted officers in the Co-operation Deptt with regard to the procedure to be followed for promotion of Clerks to the post of Assistants Head Clerks on the basis of the State wise joint seniority list.

facts.text: Joint seniority list drawn up on March 1, 1963, passed to Services Integration Department.

anchor.surface_text: A joint seniority list was drawn up on 1-3 63, The list was passed on the Services Integration Deptt. as it involved the integration of the services of the Co-operative Deptts. of the erstwhile states of Punjab Pepsu.

facts.text: Services Integration Department issued provisional joint seniority list on March 9, 1964, circulated, representations invited.

anchor.surface_text: The Integration Department issued a provisional joint seniority list on March 9, 1964, which was circulated to all the members of the staff and representations were invited. After companysidering the representations received, the final gradation list was drawn up it was approved by the Central Government and was issued by the Governor of Punjab by the numberification dated February 11, 1966.

facts.text: Final gradation list approved by Central Government, issued by Governor February 11, 1966, published in Punjab Gazette March 11, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: After companysidering the representations received, the final gradation list was drawn up it was approved by the Central Government and was issued by the Governor of Punjab by the numberification dated February 11, 1966. The numberification was published in the Punjab Gazette on March 11, 1966.

facts.text: Government of India issued directive dated April 18, 1965 to Punjab Government under Section 117 of States Re-organisation Act, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In the meanwhile, the Government of India issued a directive dated April 18, 1965, to the Punjab Government under Section 117 of the States Re-organisation Act, 1956.

facts.text: Final integrated gradation list published March 11, 1966 showed ranks of personnel from Clerks to Superintendents as on November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The final integrated gradation list published on March 11, 1966, showed the ranks of all personnel from Clerks to Superintendents as on 1-11-1956.

facts.text: Joint seniority list of Assistant Head Clerks as on March 1, 1966 issued by Punjab Government on May 20, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Soon after, a joint seniority list of Assistants Head Clerks as on March 1, 1966, depicting the position in the promoted rank, was issued by the Government of Punjab on May 20, 1966.

facts.text: High Court quashed lists published March 11, 1966 and March 20, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: As already indicated High Court dismissed the writ petition filed by the appellants and allowed the writ petition filed by the third respondent and quashed the list published on March 11, 1966, and also that published on March 20, 1970.

facts.text: High Court found directive of April 18, 1965 not applicable as integration complete before issuance.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found that the directive issued by the Central Government on April 18, 1965, was number applicable as the integration of the services had become companyplete even before the issue of the directive,

facts.text: Supreme Court held there was no integration of services by creation of divisional cadre in Pepsu or continuance after November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the approach of the High Court to the question was totally misconceived. There was numberintegration of the services by the creation of divisional cadre of junior and senior Clerks in the Pepsu area or by the companytinuance of the Divisional pattern in the two integrating units after November 1, 1956.

facts.text: Directive of Central Government binding on State under Section 117 States Re-organisation Act.

anchor.surface_text: So we held that the directive of the Central Government was binding on the State Government in the matter of integrating the two services

facts.text: Third respondent did not file objection to provisional gradation list of March 9, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The third respondent who companyplained that he was shown as junior to the appellants in the lists published on 11-3-1966 and 20-3-1970 whereas as a matter of fact he was senior to them, never filed any objection or representation to the provisional gradation list issued by the Services Integration Department on 9-3-1964.

facts.text: Appellants entitled to benefit of Clause 4 of directive dated April 18, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: We see numberreason to deny the appellants the benefit of Clause 4 of the directive.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal, by special leave, from the judgment

issues.text: Whether the directive issued by the Central Government dated April 18, 1965 under Section 117 of the States Re-organisation Act, 1956 was applicable and binding on the State Government notwithstanding that integration of services had allegedly become complete before its issue

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found that the directive issued by the Central Government on April 18, 1965, was number applicable as the integration of the services had become companyplete even before the issue of the directive, and also for the reason that Clauses 1 and 2 of the directive will apply only to promotions made on the basis of provisional gradation lists and that numberpersons were promoted on the basis of any provisional gradation list.

issues.text: Whether there was actual integration of the services of Junior and Senior Clerks of the erstwhile states of Punjab and Pepsu before the Central Government directive dated April 18, 1965

anchor.surface_text: We think that the approach of the High Court to the question was totally misconceived. There was numberintegration of the services by the creation of divisional cadre of junior and senior Clerks in the Pepsu area or by the companytinuance of the Divisional pattern in the two integrating units after November 1, 1956.

issues.text: Whether Rules 3, 14, 15, and 16 of the Punjab Services Integration Rules, 1957 permitted leaving out Pepsu Junior and Senior Clerks from integration on divisional basis without a provisional joint seniority list

anchor.surface_text: Rules 3, 14, 15, and 16 of the Punjab Services Integration Rules, 1957, held that the Junior and Senior Clerks in Pepsu companyld be left out as they were number required to be integrated into one group, particularly in view of the fact that this group of service was being maintained on divisional basis, and number on State-wise basis, and therefore, numberprovisional joint seniority list was required to be drawn up soon after the merger.

issues.text: Whether the State Government had concurrent authority with the Central Government to integrate services of the erstwhile states under the Punjab Services Integration Rules, 1957 approved by the Central Government

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on behalf of the third respondent that the State of Punjab and companycurrent authority with the Central Government to integrate the two services, and that when by the Punjab Services Integration Rules, 1957, which had been approved by the Central Government, integration had already been effected on the lines laid down in the directive of the Registrar of Co-operative Societies dated October 13, 1962,

holdings.text: There was no integration of the services by the creation of divisional cadre of junior and senior Clerks in the Pepsu area or by the continuance of the Divisional pattern in the two integrating units after November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the approach of the High Court to the question was totally misconceived. There was no integration of the services by the creation of divisional cadre of junior and senior Clerks in the Pepsu area or by the continuance of the Divisional pattern in the two integrating units after November 1, 1956.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court's approach misconceived; divisional pattern continuance and Pepsu cadre creation not integration; actual integration attempted only via 1963 joint list passed to Integration Dept.

holdings.text: The decision of the Government to constitute a single cadre of Junior and Senior Clerks was taken under the Punjab Services Integration Rules, 1957, and States Re-organisation Act, not mere administrative re-organisation.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court went wrong in assuming that the decision of the Government to constitute a single cadre of Junior and Senior Clerks in divisional offices as well as in the Office of the Registrar of Co-operative Societies was not taken under the Punjab Services Integration Rules, 1957, and under the States Re-organisation Act, but by way of re-organisation of the clerical services of the department as an administrative measure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Joint seniority list of 1963 passed to Services Integration Dept; letters from Integration Dept confirm integration process under rules; contradicts HC assumption.

holdings.text: Section 117 of the States Re-organisation Act, 1956 empowers the Central Government to give binding directions to State Governments at any time before or after the appointed day for giving effect to reorganisation provisions, and State shall comply.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of S.117 clear on scope and binding nature; precedents (Desaiah, Sharma) confirm; State admission in prior case that rules subject to S.117 directions.

holdings.text: The directive of the Central Government dated April 18, 1965 was binding on the State Government notwithstanding prior state actions on integration.
holdings.reasoning_summary: S.117 binding regardless of completion claim; no actual prior integration; overrides state directive on non-review of pre-April 1962 promotions.

holdings.text: High Court not justified in quashing the gradation lists published on March 11, 1966 and March 20, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The third respondent who complained that he was shown as junior to the appellants in the lists published on 11-3-1966 and 20-3-1970 whereas as a matter of fact he was senior to them, never filed any objection or representation to the provisional gradation list issued by the Services Integration Department on 9-3-1964. ... In these circumstances we do not think the High Court was justified in quashing the lists published on 11-3-1966 and 20-3-1970

holdings.reasoning_summary: Third respondent failed to object to provisional list of March 9, 1964 despite invitation; explanation unconvincing; lists based on that process.

holdings.text: Appellants entitled to benefit of Clause 4 of the directive dated April 18, 1965 for pay fixation in higher posts.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Directive binding under S.117; appellants' prayer for implementation granted as no reason to deny.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances we do number think the High Court was justified in quashing the lists published on 11-3-1966 and 20-3-1970 on the basis of the provisional integrated gradation list published by the Integration Department on 9-3-1964. The appellants prayer in their writ petition was for a direction to the State of Punjab and the Registrar of Cooperative Societies, Respondents 1 and 2, to implement Clause 4 pf the directive of the Central Government issued on April 18, 1965. In effect their prayer was that their pay should be fixed at the stage which they would have attained in the time scale of higher posts had they been promoted to those posts on the date set out in Clause 3 of the directive Clause 3 stated that their seniority should be companynted from the date on which their juniors stated companytinuous officiation in the higher posts because of their promotive under provisional gradation lists. As already stated, the High Court had numberoccasion to companysider the question whether this prayer companyld be granted, as it held that the directive of the Central Government had numbercontrolling operation in respect of the integration of the services in question. We see numberreason to deny the appellants the benefit of Clause 4 of the directive.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court not justified in quashing the gradation lists; appellants granted the benefit of Clause 4 of the Central Government's directive dated April 18, 1965, for pay fixation as per the time scale they would have attained.
directions: Implement Clause 4 of the directive of the Central Government dated April 18, 1965.
Fix pay of appellants at the stage they would have attained had they been promoted on the date their juniors started continuous officiation in higher posts.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the approach of the High Court to the question was totally misconceived. There was no integration of the services by the creation of divisional cadre of junior and senior Clerks in the Pepsu area or by the continuance of the Divisional pattern in the two integrating units after November 1, 1956.

In these circumstances we do number think the High Court was justified in quashing the lists published on 11-3-1966 and 20-3-1970 on the basis of the provisional integrated gradation list published by the Integration Department on 9-3-1964. The appellants prayer in their writ petition was for a direction to the State of Punjab and the Registrar of Cooperative Societies, Respondents 1 and 2, to implement Clause 4 pf the directive of the Central Government issued on April 18, 1965. In effect their prayer was that their pay should be fixed at the stage which they would have attained in the time scale of higher posts had they been promoted to those posts on the date set out in Clause 3 of the directive Clause 3 stated that their seniority should be companynted from the date on which their juniors stated companytinuous officiation in the higher posts because of their promotive under provisional gradation lists. As already stated, the High Court had numberoccasion to companysider the question whether this prayer companyld be granted, as it held that the directive of the Central Government had numbercontrolling operation in respect of the integration of the services in question. anchor.surface_text: The High Court went wrong in assuming that the decision of the Government to constitute a single cadre of Junior and Senior Clerks in divisional offices as well as in the Office of the Registrar of Co-operative Societies was not taken under the Punjab Services Integration Rules, 1957, and under the States Re-organisation Act, but by way of re-organisation of the clerical services of the department as an administrative measure.
